item.title: Facebook and Google shouldn’t ‘ride free’ on the backs of media companies, Albanese says
item.description:
PM’s comments raise expectation of levy on Meta and social media firms amid stoush over paying for news content

  • Follow our Australia news live blog for latest updates
  • Get our morning and afternoon news emails, free app or daily news podcast

Anthony Albanese has appeared to confirm the government is considering a levy on social media companies in response to tech company Meta deciding not to renew funding deals with traditional media.

Albanese said on Thursday that social media companies have a “social obligation” and should not be allowed to “essentially ride free” on the work of traditional media companies that pay journalists.

Sign up for Guardian Australia’s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup

item.title: Deep space radar site in Wales to go ahead to protect UK from ‘space warfare’
item.description:
Ministers say network of 27 radar dishes in Pembrokeshire crucial to defend against ‘increasing belligerence in space’

Plans for a network of radars tracking deep space activity to help protect the UK from “space warfare” are to go ahead in Pembrokeshire, despite the opposition of local campaigners.

The 27 radar dishes planned for the St Davids peninsula, which will be 20 metres high and can track objects as small as a football, are part of a network planned around the globe.

Continue reading...

item.title: Ocado starts trial selling everyday products in refillable packaging
item.description:
First phase of trial starts this month and includes rice and pasta

Ocado is testing offering everyday products such as pasta, rice and washing liquid in refillable packaging in a first by an online supermarket.

The scheme will trial a reusable vessel that can take food or laundry products with no extra costs for customers.

Continue reading...

item.title: NHS to offer ‘life-changing’ gene therapy for blood disorder thalassaemia
item.description:
Treatment may be offered to hundreds with severe form of disease, most often found in people of Mediterranean, Asian and Middle Eastern heritage

People living with a rare genetic blood disorder in England will be offered a “life-changing” new treatment on the NHS, in what has been described as a historic moment.

Casgevy, which is a one-off gene therapy, has been approved for use on the NHS in England for people living with a severe form of thalassaemia.

Continue reading...
